https://prez.dev/description.@value: Terms that describe the ratio of temperature to pressure (T/P) during metamorphism, defining a classification scheme based on thermal gradient that is regarded as the most appropriate for building a temporal geodynamic context for metamorphic data. Some of these terms only partly correspond to metamorphic facies fields and classic-style terminology such as Barrovian and Buchan (i.e. correspondence is not one-for-one).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Intermediate geothermal gradient or intermediate apparent thermal gradient metamorphism, characterized by average heat flow, approximating that of a steady-state geotherm for average thickness continental crust. That is, temperature increases at what is considered a normal rate with depth. Defined by apparent thermal gradients between 37.5 and 77.5°C/kbar (or 375 and 775°C/GPa), and encompassing, at the higher thermal gradient end of the range, the higher pressure part of what is traditionally referred to as Barrovian-style metamorphism. Intermediate thermal gradients encompass the middle and upper pressure range of amphibolite facies as well as high-pressure granulite (transitional to eclogite) facies. Thermal gradient is defined in terms of pressure (i.e. thermobarometric ratio) rather than depth in kilometres to avoid assumptions involving density-related conversions.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value:
Adapted from:
a) Brown, M 2006, Duality of thermal regimes is the distinctive characteristic of plate tectonics since the Neoarchean: Geology,v.34,no.11,p.961–964, doi:10.1130/G22853A.1.
b) Stüwe, K 2007, Geodynamics of the lithosphere: An introduction: Springer, Berlin, 493p.
c) Brown, M and Johnson, T 2018, Secular change in metamorphism and the onset of global plate tectonics: American Mineralogist,v.103,no.2,p.181–196, doi:10.2138/am-2018-6166.
